text: M. Gail Hamner (born 1963)Birth year from Library of Congress catalog entry, retrieved 2018-12-03. is an American scholar, author, and a professor at Syracuse University. Hamner is a Professor of Religion, while also an affiliate in the Faculty of Women and Gender Studies and Film and Screen Studies. She is the author of American Pragmatism: A Religious Genealogy. == Education == M. Gail Hamner attended Duke University where in 1985 she received her Undergraduate Bachelor of Science in Biology. She then went on to complete her Masters of Philosophical Theology at Boston University School of Theology in 1989. M. Gail Hamner then went on to obtain her Ph.D in Religion in 1997 at Duke University. == Career == M.Gail Hamner worked as a Lecturer for the Department of Religion at Duke University from 1997–1998. She became an Assistant Professor for the Department of Religion at Syracuse University up until 2005. Hamner became an Associate Professor of Religion from 2005 until 2013. In 2013, Hamner became a full Professor in her department while remaining at Syracuse University. In 2008, she became affiliated with the faculty of Women and Gender Studies at Syracuse University. As of 2015, she is affiliated with the faculty of Film and Screen Studies. Aside from lecturing and working authoring future publications, M. Gail Hamner is also the Co-Chair of the American Academy of Religion (AAR) in the field of "Religion and Media Workshop" as of 2014 and presently still holds this title. She is a member of The International Merleau-Ponty Circle, which focuses on the theory of philosophy. == Books and publications == M. Gail Hamner is the author of two books. In 2003, Hamner published her first book, American Pragmatism: A Religious Genealogy. Hamner argues about the uniqueness of pragmatism in America in relation to theology.Reviews of American Pragmatism: A Religious Genealogy: * * * The book garnered reviews in academic journals including The Journal of Religion, Transactions of the Charles S. Peirce Society, Journal of the American Academy of Religion, and Choice. In 2012, Hamner published her second book, Imaging Religion in Film: The Politics of Nostalgia, where Hamner examines the ethico-political dimensions of religion and film.Review of Imaging Religion in Film: * She is currently in the process of writing her third book, Public Affect: The Affective Dynamics of Religion in our Global 'public sphere' as felt through the Sci-Fi Feminine. Her most noted publication is Akira Kurosawa: "What is a Thing?"; Posing the Religious in Dress Uzala. == Controversy == In 2016, M. Gail Hamner faced backlash for not playing an Israeli film in front of her students and colleagues at a conference for "The Place of Religion in Film." Due to ongoing issues in the Middle East and BDS movements in Syracuse, Hamner emailed filmmaker Shimon Dotan about her reluctance to show his documentary, "The Settlers", due to certain groups boycotting Israel at Syracuse University. She issued a public apology through the Syracuse University following the controversy. == References == Category:1963 births Category:Living people Category:American religion academics Category:Duke University alumni Category:Boston University School of Theology alumni Category:Syracuse University faculty Category:20th- century American women writers Category:21st-century American women writers Category:20th-century American non-fiction writers Category:21st-century American non-fiction writers Category:American women non-fiction writers
